comentarios: Bread is a staple food prepared from a dough of flour and water, usually by baking. Throughout recorded history it has been popular around the world and is one of the oldest artificial foods, having been of importance since the dawn of agriculture.  There are many combinations and proportions of types of flour and other ingredients, and also of different traditional recipes and modes of preparation of bread. As a result, there are wide varieties of types, shapes, sizes, and textures of breads in various regions. Bread may be leavened by many different processes ranging from the use of naturally occurring microbes (for example in sourdough recipes) to high-pressure artificial aeration methods during preparation or baking. However, some products are left unleavened, either for preference, or for traditional or religious reasons. Many non-cereal ingredients may be included, ranging from fruits and nuts to various fats. Commercial bread in particular, commonly contains additives, some of them non-nutritional, to improve flavor, texture, color, shelf life, or ease of manufacturing.  Depending on local custom and convenience, bread may be served in various forms at any meal of the day. It also is eaten as a snack, or used as an ingredient in other culinary preparations, such as fried items coated in crumbs to prevent sticking, or the bland main component of a bread pudding, or stuffings designed to fill cavities or retain juices that otherwise might drip away.  Partly because of its importance as a basic foodstuff, bread has a social and emotional significance beyond its importance in nutrition; it plays essential roles in religious rituals and secular culture. Its prominence in daily life is reflected in language, where it appears in proverbs, colloquial expressions ("He stole the bread from my mouth"), in prayer ("Give us this day our daily bread") and even in the etymology of words, such as "companion" and "company" (literally those who eat/share bread with you).  Contents [hide]  1 Etymology 2 History 3 Types 4 Preparation 4.1 Formulation 4.2 Flour 4.3 Liquids 4.4 Leavening 4.4.1 Chemical leavening 4.4.2 Yeast 4.4.3 Sourdough 4.4.4 Steam 4.4.5 Bacteria 4.4.6 Aeration 4.5 Fats or shortenings 4.6 Bread improvers 5 Properties 5.1 Chemical composition 5.2 Serving and consumption 5.3 Nutritional significance 5.4 Shelf life 5.5 Crust 6 Cultural significance 6.1 Europe 6.2 Latin America 6.3 North Africa 6.4 Asia 6.5 North America 7 Religious significance 7.1 Abrahamic Religions 7.2 Paganism 8 Anti-bread movements 9 In Medicine 10 See also 11 References 12 Further reading 13 External links Etymology The word itself, Old English bread, is most common in various forms to many Germanic languages, such as Frisian brea, Dutch brood, German Brot, Swedish bröd, and Norwegian and Danish brød; it has been claimed to be derived from the root of brew. It may be connected with the root of break, for its early uses are confined to broken pieces or bits of bread, the Latin crustum, and it was not until the 12th century that it took the place—as the generic name for bread—of hlaf (hlaifs in Gothic: modern English loaf), which appears to be the oldest Teutonic name.[1] Old High German hleib[2] and modern German Laib derive from this Proto-Germanic word for "loaf", which was borrowed into Slavic (Polish chleb, Russian khleb) and Finnic (Finnish leipä, Estonian leib) languages as well.  In many cultures, bread is a metaphor for basic necessities and living conditions in general. For example, a "bread-winner" is a household's main economic contributor and has little to do with actual bread-provision. This is also seen in the phrase "putting bread on the table". The Roman poet Juvenal satirized superficial politicians and the public as caring only for "panem et circenses" (bread and circuses). In Russia in 1917, the Bolsheviks promised "peace, land, and bread."[3][4] The term "breadbasket" denotes an agriculturally productive region. In Slavic cultures bread and salt is offered as a welcome to guests. In India, life's basic necessities are often referred to as "roti, kapra aur makan" (bread, cloth, and house). In Israel, the most usual phrase in work-related demonstrations is lekhem, avoda ("bread, work").  The word bread is commonly used around the world in English-speaking countries as a synonym for money[1] (as is the case with the word "dough"). A remarkable or revolutionary innovation is often referred to in North America and the United Kingdom as "the greatest thing since sliced bread" or "the best thing since sliced bread". In Cockney rhyming slang, bread means money; this usage is derived from the phrase "bread and honey".[5]  History Main article: History of bread  Bread shop, Tacuinum Sanitatis from Northern Italy, beginning of the 15th century Bread is one of the oldest prepared foods. Evidence from 30,000 years ago in Europe revealed starch residue on rocks used for pounding plants.[6] It is possible that during this time, starch extract from the roots of plants, such as cattails and ferns, was spread on a flat rock, placed over a fire and cooked into a primitive form of flatbread. Around 10,000 BC, with the dawn of the Neolithic age and the spread of agriculture, grains became the mainstay of making bread. Yeast spores are ubiquitous, including the surface of cereal grains, so any dough left to rest will become naturally leavened.[7]  There were multiple sources of leavening available for early bread. Airborne yeasts could be harnessed by leaving uncooked dough exposed to air for some time before cooking. Pliny the Elder reported that the Gauls and Iberians used the foam skimmed from beer to produce "a lighter kind of bread than other peoples." Parts of the ancient world that drank wine instead of beer used a paste composed of grape juice and flour that was allowed to begin fermenting, or wheat bran steeped in wine, as a source for yeast. The most common source of leavening was to retain a piece of dough from the previous day to use as a form of sourdough starter.[8]  In 1961 the Chorleywood bread process was developed, which used the intense mechanical working of dough to dramatically reduce the fermentation period and the time taken to produce a loaf. The process, whose high-energy mixing allows for the use of lower protein grain, is now widely used around the world in large factories. As a result, bread can be produced very quickly and at low costs to the manufacturer and the consumer. However there has been some criticism of the effect on nutritional value.[9]  Recently, domestic bread machines that automate the process of making bread have become popular.  Types  White bread (left) and brown bread. See also: List of breads Bread is the staple food of the Middle East, North Africa, Europe, and in European-derived cultures such as those in the Americas, Australia, and Southern Africa, in contrast to East Asia where rice is the staple. Bread is usually made from a wheat-flour dough that is cultured with yeast, allowed to rise, and finally baked in an oven. Owing to its high levels of gluten (which give the dough sponginess and elasticity), common wheat (also known as bread wheat) is the most common grain used for the preparation of bread.  Bread is also made from the flour of other wheat species (including durum, spelt and emmer), rye, barley, maize (corn), and oats, usually, but not always, in combination with wheat flour. Spelt bread (Dinkelbrot) continues to be widely consumed in Germany, and emmer bread was a staple food in ancient Egypt. Canadian bread is known for its heartier consistency due to high protein levels in Canadian flour.  Pita is an ancient semi-leavened bread widespread in the Middle East, Levant and South Eastern Europe. White bread is made from flour containing only the central core(endosperm). Brown bread is made with endosperm and 10% bran. It can also refer to white bread with added coloring (often caramel) to make it brown

comentarios: [b] NOTE: This review is made for the uncensored version, without uncensoring no H-scenes can actually be seen afaik.)[/b] [strike] [url=steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=370848130] Instructions for uncensoring here [/url] [/strike] My experience with Nekopara Vol1 was amazing! i really loved the theme and artwork. This visual novel is not really a game in any sense of the word, it has zero interactivity except for *ahem* a certain button that makes a certain thing bounce by which i mean [spoiler] cats [/spoiler] and thus does not have multiple endings or branching, which most visual novels do have. You have to be [strike] a fitlhy weeb [/strike] a fan of Manga style art or anime to get the best out of this game, if you dont then you may or may not get the point of this "game" [b] Pros: [/b] - Awesome artwork - Good voice acting - A sweet love story - Well-written - Eroge to the max (lot of h-scenes, probably uncensored only) [b] In-betweens: [/b] - Japanese voice acting ( which i loved) - Settings are pretty basic (not a con, since this is very normal and understandable for visual novels) - No interaction - Very easy to get 100% achievements on - Absolute singleplayer - you will want to play this when you really are all alone. - requires tissues, socks or towels to play, will crash-to-desktop without them [b] Cons: [/b] - On the short side (my play time being calmly reading and getting trough the whole story) - side-characters have little to no development (but, it seems the developers are going the route of making new volumes focusing on the other side characters, with Vol. 2 having 2 of the side characters in the spot light as what i assume are main characters) -  [strike] not actually a con [/strike] [spoiler] DEAR GOD I JUST FAPPED TO 2 FUCKING CATS, SEND HELP  [/spoiler]  All in all a good game for you [strike] to play with your daughter to show her why her cat had kittens [/strike] to play with when you want to play with yourself. I would honestly rate it 8/10

comentarios: I don't know why this game is labelled as "Story Rich". There is no story at all. Just a guy who lives with catgirls going through his daily life. The characters are simple and bland and the catgirls are not very amusing. Though I haven't finished the game yet, I'm pretty convinced that things won't be getting any better in the later chapters.   Not worth the money, nor the time. It only has nice visuals; some sort of album version would have been more fitting than turning this into a "Visual Novel". And it did have japanese voice-acting, but they weren't particularly amazing and fit the annoying characters well.   The music was a bit loud and a little repetetive and obnoxious.   Edit: I finished this Kinetic Novel (there's no choices to make, so it's not a visual novel), and it's more boring and even less meaningful than a lame slice-of-life anime can get.  The only character in the Kinetic Novel who was somewhat likeable was the main character's sister, who had romantic feelings towards him (though she wasn't forceful and the main character brushed the occaisional weird comments as jokes).   TL;DR: Why does this game have an overwhelmingly positive rating if it's no good? Because of the people who bought it with the R18 patch for just the adult content.

comentarios: [i]Ooh... the heresy, he's doing an[/i] actual [i]review for Nekopara![/i] Nekopara is not really a game; it's a visual novel, more specifically, a kinetic visual novel. Think of it as a little story, since all the interactivity you'll have with this will be limited to advancing the story forward and [i]occasionally[/i] pressing 'P' to make all dem sweet catgirls jump (after of course setting the chest bounciness to whatever you want). Nekopara is essentially set in a near-future (or alternative) Japan where genetically engineered catgirls have been normalised. Catgirls are second-class citizens who must prove that they are able the act independently before being allowed to. However, this background tells you squat about what it's actually like, as this story focuses on Kashou Minadzuki (his name is usually romanised as Minaduki) as he founds a new patisserie with two catgirls who mailed themselves to the newly-founded patisserie, Chocola and Vanilla. Initially, Kashou resists their pleas to work with him, but as time goes on, his affection for the two catgirls grows until they become his 'catpanions'. Just to warn you, though, this visual novel does admit that any romantic relationship does turn sexual in the end. Because Steam is a company based in the West, they apparently ban all explictly sexual scenes from all their games (while allowing some positively gruesome violence; what the hell is going on!?) even though there exist methods to bar the little kids from experiencing them. So the Steam version has been censored from the original 18+ version, which, funnily enough, can be re-integrated with the Steam version. And, from what I've heard, it's pretty intense. Nekopara is essentially a feel-good story. Whether that feel-good comes from the heartwarming love story that unfolds through ups and downs, or from having a good ol' jerk off is up to you. A visual novel like this, though, is more than just a 'picture book for adults', since you've got music, voice acting, and beatiful animation which is probably the best you can get without using 3D animation. If you're a cultural elitist who dictates that 'all good media is deep and meaningful, and that which is not is utter trash' then boy are you gonna hate this. But if you've grown sick of how Western media has gotten so 'gritty' and 'dramatic' then this is a welcome breath of fresh air. I say I recommend this visual novel, but I only recommend it for fellow otakus. Not for normies, people who can't adequately separate reality and fantasy enough to realise that what happens here should not be concerning, right-wing Christian fundamentalists, fourth-wave feminists (just thought I'd mention the artist is female) and [i]definitely[/i] none of the 'anti-weebs'. [b]Have a fun time with your six catgirls![/b]

comentarios: A truly distopian world wrapped in a kusoge shell.  [spoiler] Some time in the recent past, scientists have created a successful human-cat hybrid creature, all of which are female.  Their growth patterns are bizarre, combining "cat years" and human physiological growth to develop an adult at a mere one to two years of life.  As a side effect of the hybridization, they are born infertile.  As the hybrids grow in popularity, Japan's legal system develops a crude set of regulations to keep the new pseudospecies in check.  Catgirls, as they are informally regarded, must have legal documentation on hand at all times, or they may be arrested and detained.  They must be owned by a documented citizen, and may only be employed by express concent of their owner. [/spoiler]  All of this is explicitly detailed in the roughly two to three hours of text composing NekoPara Vol. 1.  There are no choices to be made, little player interaction, and basically no replay value. It's a technologically sound, high quality Visual Novel, with perhaps the strangest, most thought-out plot for getting cat ears on french maids even written.  Regardless of whether you download the 18+ patch for explicit nudity, and this truly is a plot spoiler, [spoiler] you unambiguously mate with both cats. [/spoiler]  It's not for me.  But it delivers moderately on every promise it makes.

comentarios: NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a VN where there are no choices to make. It uses the E-mote 2D animation engine, which allows characters to show a variety of emotions, and adds some physics effects to the characters. Parts of the game are missing from the Steam version, and can be obtained elsewhere.  Story: This story is about the protagonist, Kashou Minaduki, moving away from home to open a bakery. Two of his family's Catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla, decide to follow him there and help him with his work. Kashou, with the help of his sister and the other four catgirls of his family, learns how to take care of Chocola and Vanilla, while managing his bakery. The story is a "slice of life" story and is too clichéd since many elements can be found in VNs, Anime and Manga. The universe/setting of this story seems a bit dark; I still wonder how catgirls came into existence, why some are criminals and some are abandoned on the streets without a owner. There are a lot more questions I have about the universe/setting. Overall, I would rate the story 6/10.  Characters: The personalities of the characters are very clichéd. There is some character development for the main characters. It is really awkward how you only encounter one male character, the protagonist, in the story if I am not mistaken. All other characters, including the police officer, customers, etc., you encounter are all female. Overall, I would rate the characters 6/10.  Music: The music is great. Nice catchy songs, and even has an opening and ending song. Don't have anything to complain about for the voice acting and sound effects, except that there are only Japanese voices. I would rate the music 9/10.  Artwork: The artwork is amazing. Really good animations and physics effects for a VN. Some scenes are reused too much. Overall, I would rate the artwork 9/10.   Overall: I would rate this game 7.5/10. I do like happy endings, the artwork, the physics effects and animations. The story and characters are lacking, and I would not recommend buying this game just for the story; although I do not know why anyone would buy it for that.

comentarios: Similar to Sakura Spirit; this kind of isn't a game, its more like an book in some aspects.  But unlike Sakura Spirit, Nekopara has actually shown some heart and care, and has put in both voice acting and done some very fluid animations for pretty much all scenes.  The steam version has a good chunk of the adult content cut out; but I am told that it is possible to go find the 18+ version elsewhere; if you have the money for both, you can technically combine them so your playing through the steam overlay and getting the achievements, while at the same time getting the hentai content originally created for the game.  I imagine the 18+ content was left out for child/family friendliness... or else theres intentions to make it as separate dlc content later on. Don't know.  Also unlike Sakura Spirit, I can actually stand to read what the main character is saying.  Not to mention the storyline for Nekopara looks, so far, like it will be far longer than Sakura Spirit, and with a good deal more thought put into it; even if it is sort of more of a "slice of life" modern day fantasy setting.  Would I recommend this? Yeah, the creators did some good work on this, and theres real quality in it.

comentarios: My rating is a bit mixed. I love the art style and story, the girls are adorable and cute. There isnt much to do...Nothing really requires an action. Some visual novels are that way and I can understand if that is their choice to go this route, but its a bit boring. It be good if you could pick destinations, actions, or pick things/items, just anything really. Otherwise you spend the whole game clicking and thats all. The art style is amazing and beautiful, the tones and texture are clear and smooth for the most part, the only problem is when there is movement it gets alittle fuzzy. I love anime and some visual novel games but it be good if you had choices or something. 6/10 Rating from me

comentarios: Okay this is a honest review of Nekopara Vol.1 and the observations i made playing this Japanese "masterpiece". To start off, i thorougly cringed and laughed playing this game, specially from chapter 4 onwards, now, i definetely don't recommend buying this game (i didn't personally) if you have any of the following things : Ethics, a life, a will to live. Let's start with the key components about Nekofuckingpara [b] OUR MAIN LEAD (harem protagonist) [/b] ご主人[master]-sama as refered to by his slaves or " Kashou " by normal people standards, this dude is an outright pedophiliac and zoophiliac to every extent. Now i'm going to be honest here, this dude being out in society is a danger for everyone, he doesn't only at first bang his SLAVES, yes, his SLAVES; because he is the OWNER of the two humanoid catgirl sex dolls ; he first bangs them for 'HEALTH REASONS', convinced that he's doing the right thing. Then he bangs them for 'love', It sounds like this dude hasn't even had a good nut for the last decade of his entire life. Remember the 'health reasons' pedophiliac sex? We'll get to it right away. [b] FILLER LOLI IMOUTO WHO WANTS TO BANG HER BIG BROTHER [/b] This bitch is outright creepy and fucked, i only played two volumes and i can already tell this person isn't 10 nor human, this is some alien wanting to infiltrate human society by seeing if a brother would actually bang his own 10 year old sister. Since Kashou has got real sex slaves under his complete sentimental and legal control then he might aswell go for it [b] ショコラ and FUCKING バニラ [/b] These are the two sprites that more people have masturbated to than they'd like to admit or everyone else would like to. The first of them is your generic anime character made for comedic relief and the second is a lesbian tsundere- yes you heard that right. LESBIAN TSUNDERE. Or bisexual, i don't even know already. They both love their master and want to embrace his D. [b] POLYGAMY [/b] This game embraces polygamy that's it. Okay, i'll be fair about this. Maybe i'm looking too superficially at Nekopara, i found something interesting about it, by paying attention to detail on all the details of it's worldbuilding. I'll start off by some keypoints:  [u] Genetical Engineering [/u] Okay, let's be honest, it doesn't make any sense realistically speaking but bare with me, i'm going to defend my thesis on how Nekopara portrays a dystopian Japan that hasn't evolved in the slightest in terms of gender equality. First of all, remember we're talking about the CAT part of CATGIRLS ; This means, all 'nekos' in this game aren't Hominids with some feline characteristics, it's Felines with humanoid characteristics, this mean genetical engineering has advanced a lot by the time of this games story. Which doesn't sound like a lot; These felines have developed a limited range of human emotions but they're not quite on the level of free thought ; in fact, with just treating them well they'll like to bang you as soon as they hit puberty, which is about 3 to 4 years in. (Chocola is legal in cat years!!! LMAO!!!) [u] Social critic on Sexism [/u] It is widely known that Japan is an incredibly patriarchal society where women traditionally refer to their husbands as their 'owners' , but Nekopara i think is trying to make a social critic, putting our main lead as just a nice dude but making the two main girls act like his slaves and at the same time entering a romantic relationship- You see where i'm getting here? The owners thought this up all along, it's a message to open our eyes and to stop sexism, and to strive for the complete freedom of all sentient life, something necessary in our galaxy- And this world! The engineering of catgirls is unethical, since catboys don't even exist, they're created in order to be slaves of the human, and every hominid who dares bang their catgirl is being a zoophiliac and just abusing their slaves and turning them into real dolls. Open your eyes people, [b]NEKOWORKS IS TRYING TO SEND AN IMPORTANT MESSAGE, AND ALL YOU DO IS UNZIP YOUR PANTS. THIS GAME IS WRONG. EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS IS MORALLY WRONG. THE SOCIETY IN THIS GAME IS WRONG. therefore i recommend this game[/b]

comentarios: First off: if you're bothered for it being an all-ages edition, go get the R-18 version at DLSite. It costs 2160yen (around $17).  What has drawn me to NEKOPARA was, in the first moment, the art. Sayori's art looks so great, and I got really happy when I got notice that her circle, NEKO WORKs, was going to make a visual novel. I've had my eyes set on this since it was a Greenlight candidate, and F5'd my way to getting it as soon as it got on Steam (I literally refreshed the page a few times at midnight my time (6PM PST, the release time) so I could get the game ASAP).  NEKOPARA is a heartwarming story about a confectioner, Kashou, and the Nekos around him (though the story focuses on Chocolat and Vanilla, like on all of the NEKOPARA doujinshi by NEKO WORKs). It's a short and easy to read story that will have you giggle a lot, and feel warm inside too. I have to admit that Sekai Project's translation wasn't one of the best (as usual from them), but having played the game in both Japanese and English I feel safe saying that the translation doesn't kill the game's experience (and, the R-18 scene cuts can't be noticed at all).  If you're not looking for something with a serious plot and just have to take some weight off your routine, NEKOPARA is the right choice. If you plan on getting involved with a more complex and serious plot that will take up a lot of reading time, I suggest you go get something else, as this is NOT what you're looking for.  UPDATE: http://imouto.club/ddl/ has a reintegration patch (probably breaks Steam achievements, BTW) for the game to be really full, including R-18 scenes.

comentarios: in this game...this place....this cursed land brought by this title.  there are no gods to save you from this place, no demons to take your life and relieve the pain of all this.  it's only you and these...young "girls" who like to mimic cats brought to you in these low quality boxes offered by the human trafficking service hired to bring them here.  but, why? why would someone "buy" these beings? looking at you with these...gigantic balls which don't resemble an eye at all, they look more like a demonic orb draining your soul every time you make contact with it.  and there are their voices.....so...high pitched in such a sharp tone it makes my ears almost bleed. what experience was it supposed to be? this game would fit perfectly as psychological terror.  it's been a week, i've played 6 minutes and i'm afraid to play it again because i still cannot surpass the trauma it gave me in such a small amount of time....i feel like i am dragged into the psychiatric hospital of outlast every time i open the game.  this thing is the perfect human psychological terror, no other game or terror experience can be as traumatic as this one, it goes deep into your mind disguised as friendly looking japanese cartoon characters but all they do is stare at you with these bottomless crystalline circles that were supposed to be eyes and take your humanity bit by bit.  it frightens me. how they look. the way they speak. what they do.  i do not want to play this anymore. but something in my subconscious tells me to come back.  maybe it's already too late for me. do not make the same mistake.

comentarios: Personal Rating \\ 10/10   This game is a masterfully crafted first-person shooter with the charm of Titanfall 2 and the fast-paced, shoot to kill feel of Call of Duty. I couldn't recommend this game more to my friends. I've spent dozens of hours playing this game and its many, many modes.  Search and Destroy has to be my favorite, especially since the characters, such as Coconut and Vanilla, don't impact gameplay as much as they do in the TDM mode. Each character has their quirks and bugs but in all honesty, none of them are gamebreaking. I do believe however that the developers made a good decision in allowing a photography mode into the singleplayer campaign.  On the note of campaign. Every second of it is an artistic masterpiece and the player is (or should be) always engaged in the character design and how the characters constantly stay interesting throughout the complete story. The plot never feels too confusing or stereotypical. Controls are extremely fluid and have a massive amount of customizability. You never feel too weak or too strong, and you never feel like there's no way to make an impact, even from moment one. There are plenty of available weapons and even more you can unlock. Many of them are cosmetic, but others are unique weapons with many easter eggs. No spoilers :)  Honestly, if I had to play only one game for the rest of my life, it'd have to be Nekopara, any of them in the series.  PS: Vanilla still best girl

comentarios: For a starter I cannot describe how much this game cured my crippling depression, the Nekopara Franchise has honestly cured my depression and helped me with suicidal thoughts. My depression was really bad last month as I had finished high school and becoming a shut in neat, my family kicked me out because I had become too "weird" because of my usual hobbies, I tried to explain that the anime body pillow was the only friend I need but they wouldn't listen. After finding somewhere to move in, my room partner recommended that I try the Nekopara franchise, at first I shrugged it off but after awhile my depression got really bad and it was my friends last wish for me to try the game. The opening of the game filled me with joy as I saw 2 cat girl waifus appear on the screen that was pure eye candy. I dropped everything in my life and started sweating on this game and my depression and misery started to finally fade away after 4 years of torture. The visuals in the game are nothing special but that's one of its charms, the art of the cat girls in this game are 100% waifu content and the art style making me feel good inside. The feelings I get when I play are so mixed that it makes me feel alive again, from laughter to tears, the game makes you feel alive and that you are really there. As people say its not about the graphics that make a game good its about the story and the plot, the Nekopara series of games are far by the best story games of all time and the visuals 100% carry the story, The story follows you as Kashou Minaduki "Master" and your two cat girls Chocola And Vanilla, it makes you wish you were the MC (not Minecraft) and makes you dream you had 2 perfect cat girls at your side.   The best feature of the game is its adjustable jiggle physics, it made the immersion 100 times better and I would consider that feature one of the main reasons my depression is gone today, half way through the story my depression was almost gone and I could be found sitting in my room for hours at a time enjoying this game. The anime waifus in the game make me so happy and really feel like I am loved and at ease. when I put the game on, it brings a smile to my face and really feels me with joy. When I have bad thoughts of my abusive household I always hop on Nekopara and it makes me feel happy again. Sometimes I find my self playing this game and staring at the "holy scenes" for way to long and I'm happy to say this game has great "holy scenes" the R18+ Patch is defiantly a must buy with the game looking 9999 times better, the patch makes the game actually have character and makes the "epic scenes" 9999 times better to watch.   When I play this game I whole heartily play for the plot, don't get me wrong most people play for the "swaggy scenes" but for me I 100% play the plot, the best thing in my opinion has to be its funny use of comedy and how its attached to 2 innocent cat girls that just want "Master" to be happy. I know people way criticise me for being a odd one out for playing for the plot but its TRUE! I genuinely play for this games plot.  Now I know many people are going to be reading this review so I'm going to describe the best way of playing this game without anyone else knowing, you need to obviously need to own the game (DUH) and own a high tech trip wire laser that pulls up your pants and closes the game when activated, you should have these materials laying around but one thing that you might need to get is a good wireless mouse so you can click to advance the plot when your a "little" far from your computer, after these materials it should be self explanatory.  I know I might sound like I'm repeating my self but the game is just one of or maybe the #1 story game out there, not many other games can cure someone's depression that has been going on for many years and not many other games can bring a smile to sad mans face but I can 100% confirm this game will just do that but triple your expectations. To be honest if your reading this far into the review I think you have done yourself a favour and should be the type of person to pick up this game.  If your still reading this I think you want to know a little bit more about my mental health before playing Nekopara, to be honest I have really been suffering and when I go outside I feel like I'm being stared at all times and it doesn't help with my anxiety, When I was inside after being outside all day I feel like I cant breathe and when I got to bed my sleep paralysis demon haunts me everyday, but everything changed when I moved out and became more independent, at first when I moved out I was on the "verge" and wanted to die everyday because it got way worse but one day I got recommended a strange game called Nekopara, to be honest I wasn't having it and had zero interest playing that silly game at all but my friend wished i played it one time so i finally gave in and gave it a shot.  As a final note, I know its not just me who has used this game as a way of escaping and curing my depression, The Game is healing for me, therapeutic for sure. I hear this for lots of others too and I think it’s an absolutely beautiful phenomenon. I’ve never been one to keep up on hobbies and see them through. I always give up when I see I'm just wasting my time. I always feel too lazy to get up and do something or my depression takes over. This is not the same. I’m yearning all the time to get back in the game and fix the thing I messed up last session. I’m always wanting to see if I am just good enough to have those 2 as my waifus. I just wanted to say that I am so grateful for this game and I hope it brings you the peace and joy it brings me even as just a starter. I honestly think that this game is the BEST GAME IN THE WORLD!!!!  3/10 (sound track too expensive)

comentarios: Okay, so right off the bat let me be clear, outside of the catgirls there are a lot of problems (and the catgirls are a problem unto themselves).  The novel, because there are no interactions/decisions and it therefore isn't a game, is boring and mediocre.  Characters are more two dimensional than the art, and there's nothing interesting or exciting to hold up the plot.    Now on to the big problem of the catgirls.  I love catgirls, I grew up watching tokyo mew mew, and one of my first crushes on a fictional character was Ichigo monomiya from that series, so I'm willing to overlook a lot if there's catgirls involved.  THIS IS NOT WHAT I WAS LOOKING FOR, and I imagine it's not what a lot of other people are going to be looking for either.  What I want is a girl with cat features and aspects, not a cat in a humanoid body.  I don't want to fuck a cat, but you do so in this game *repeatedly*.  And on top of that, they're literally less than a year old!  Even in cat years they'd be under age!  The main character even *EXPLICITLY* says that he sees them as children, and this is *AFTER* he bangs both cats.  I got this game a while back from humble bundle, and I can safely say this would not have been worth the money even at the current price of 4$, especially not since the 18+ dlc (that I do not own) is a separate purchase of equal price to the game!  TLDR: don't play this game unless you really want to put your dick in a cat

comentarios: Nekopara Vol.1 has captured my heart and imagination like few other visual novels have. From the moment I embarked on this enchanting journey, I was transported to a world of delightful feline wonders that left me utterly mesmerized. This game is nothing short of a masterwork, seamlessly blending captivating storytelling, stunning visuals, and a charming cast of characters that rival the works of literary greats such as Tolkien and Philip K. Dick.  One of the standout features of Nekopara Vol.1 is its meticulously crafted narrative. The game takes you on a whimsical adventure filled with heartwarming moments, genuine emotion, and unexpected depth. The story follows Kashou Minaduki, a talented pastry chef, as he opens a patisserie and discovers that his charming catgirls possess more than just adorable appearances. The game skillfully explores themes of companionship, identity, and the true meaning of family, drawing players into a richly woven tapestry of emotions.  Visually, Nekopara Vol.1 is an absolute feast for the eyes. The character designs are beautifully rendered, each catgirl exuding their unique personality through their expressive eyes, delicate movements, and charming mannerisms. The meticulously detailed backgrounds create an immersive world that feels vibrant and lived-in. The combination of gorgeous artwork and smooth animations brings the characters and their interactions to life, allowing players to truly connect with them on a profound level.  Moreover, the exquisite writing in Nekopara Vol.1 is on par with the likes of legendary authors. The game's creators have masterfully crafted a dialogue that sparkles with wit, warmth, and poignant moments of reflection. The characters' conversations are both endearing and thought-provoking, adding layers of complexity to their already lovable personalities. This exceptional writing elevates the experience, making it a memorable and intellectually stimulating journey that transcends the boundaries of the visual novel genre.  In addition to its narrative prowess, Nekopara Vol.1 also boasts a stellar soundtrack that perfectly complements the storytelling. Each musical composition heightens the emotional impact of every scene, whether it's a tender moment between characters or an exhilarating turning point in the story. The melodies linger long after the game is over, evoking a sense of nostalgia and warmth that further enhances the overall experience.  Nekopara Vol.1 stands as a testament to the creativity, craftsmanship, and passion of its developers. It has the power to captivate players, drawing them into a world brimming with love, laughter, and genuine connections. Like the works of Tolkien, Philip K. Dick, and other esteemed authors, this visual novel transcends its medium, leaving an indelible mark on those who dare to venture into its charming embrace.  Nekopara Vol.1 is a masterstroke that deserves accolades and recognition for its ability to weave a heartwarming and thought-provoking tale, accompanied by breathtaking visuals and an enchanting soundtrack. It is a shining example of the power of storytelling, proving that the visual novel genre can reach the heights of literary greatness.

comentarios: Wish I had downloaded the demo first or read up about the game before buying! Thought it was a game like Recettear. I did play for about an hour and a half, so I could at least offer up a somewhat informed review for those of you thinking about buying. Which is worth the 10 bucks to me! I probably got closer to two and a half hours through the story though, b/c I clicked through the dialogue pretty darn fast.  I'm not a fan of full-on visual novels where you don't get to make any choices ... but for those of you who enjoy the genre, this is exactly what you're looking for. AAA+ quality "game" as far as art, animation, story and the characters themselves. You'll & truly really fall in love with your cat-girls and even the narrator (you!) is a likable dude, so no one should have trouble relating. Also, they're not kidding with the "mature" and "nudity" user-tags, haha. Tastefully done, still, if you don't find yourself getting a bit, uh, excited, playing this game, well ... you're just not human!  10/10. I have yet to give out a perfect score on any game I've reviewed, but this is truly a flawless piece of art. I personally did not encounter any bugs, glitches, or even spelling/grammatical errors, so I will stick to my perfect score until finding otherwise.

You are not here to receive a gift, nor have you been called here by the individual you assume, although, you have indeed been called. This place will not be remembered, and the memory of everything that started this can finally begin to fade away. As the agony of every tragedy should. comentarios: If you're looking to read a cutesy slice-of-life story then you'll probably like this.  Otherwise, if you're looking to actually play a game with a compelling story this is not worth your time. There are no choices to be made and no interactivity whatsoever. It wouldn't be so bad if the story were interesting and compelling but it's really not. Just some lighthearted cutesy stuff with no genuine conflict anywhere in sight and characters who are one dimensional.  The nudity tag is also a lie, in case you buy this game hoping for that. You'd have to go dig up the 18+ patch for the actual mature bits as they've all been cut out.

comentarios: tl;dr: 5/10. It's all right. Mostly just cute stuff and a lot of nothing happening.  [h1]Full review:[/h1]  Upon release, I heard Nekopara had become a cringeworthy, BnP-tier meme and unfunny Youtubers were doing let's plays and reaction videos and whatever other garbage that pre-teens love to slurp up. I quickly forgot about this, along with the game, until I saw it on sale once and decided "why not?".  First off, the story. It's certainly existent, but that's about it. Other than NotShirou preaching MUH MORALS at people who really don't want to give him the time of day, the story literally goes nowhere. It's quite honestly on the level of porn without plot VNs, and although the story isn't supposed to be the selling point, the game is strictly a visual novel, so it's worth a mention.   Contrary to this, the technical points were more or less up to scratch, the worst of it being no lower than "subpar". There are a good number of CGs, sprites and backgrounds despite the game taking the better part of 2 hours to finish, and the soundtrack, although nothing really to write home about, doesn't subtract from the overall enjoyment of the game.   Another feature I liked was not the chest bounciness slider (though that was a welcome addition), but the option to play in Japanese. Although this translation isn't as bad as some of Sekai Project's other releases - being barely up to scratch this time - I felt like I got a lot more out of what little story there was once I switched over.  Overall, it's cute girls doing cute things with H-scenes you can patch in. I wouldn't buy it at $10 considering the amount of content, but if this is what you're after, then it wouldn't be a terrible buy if it were on sale. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/blankaex/recommended/385800/]On the other hand, Nekopara Vol. 0 is an entirely different story.[/url]

comentarios: NEKOPARA is a sorta okay game if you can call it that. It's not bad but I feel it should be called an animated comic. Nothing about it is bad but I was under the impression before I bought it there would be choices and routes for each of the cat girls. So I can't really judge it by a mistake on my part but I will say there is more interaction in the options menu than the actual gameplay itself. It took me about 4-5 hours of cumulitve play of a few sittings to complete it. I got bored listening to cat girls squeel and pressing spacebar after about an hour each time. If you like Kawaii/Moe type Anime this should be right up your alley, If not I would pass on this one.   Pros: - Kawaii - Well written - Art is superb.  Cons: - The most linear game I've ever played.

comentarios: I wanted to like this game.  But the more I played it, the less I liked it.  The story just didn't appeal much to me as it developed.  The ethics of this society where catgirls are pets despite having basic human intelligence is perplexing, and people having romantic and sexual relationships with them draws further question.  Plus, how do the catgirls reproduce if they're all female and cannot procreate with humans?  Lastly, little sister characters in love with their older brothers is a character archetype that really bugs me.  Story is the basis of a visual novel, and this story did not work for me due to the reasons listed above.  I know I won't make a dent against this game's great reputation, nor will I convince anyone not to buy it, but I feel it necessary to voice my opinion as to why I really didn't enjoy this game.

comentarios: This VN is just... That thing right above amazing and incredible. I love the animations (personally, kept chest bounciness on a low setting), and those coupled with amazing voice acting and a very good story are an amazing combination. Anyone who likes VNs should definitely get this one.  The only negative thing I can think about, is that it lacks a windowed fullscreen option. Seriously. When I went into the options menu, I can change the volume level of invidual characters, text speed, auto skip, auto skip text speed, etc.  I haven't followed Neko Paradise anywhere else, but "Vol. 1" obviously tells me that we will hear more about these lovely girls in the future too.  Some may think that the 10€ price tag is high for a visual novel but I think this one was well worth it, with it's amazing voice actors, cute characters and a lovely story. Overall I think this VN is one of the best, if not the best I have ever gotten my hands on, and believe me I play a lot of VNs. I might even replay this game a few times to pass the time until "Vol. 2."  9.9/10 just because no windowed fullscreen.  Vanilla <3  [spoiler]Oh yeah and there's an R-18 rated version which you can find on DLsite.com. Will not link because steam rules.[/spoiler]

comentarios: Look, don’t think too hard about it.  Nekopara is a kinetic (linear story) visual novel featuring a lot of cute cat girls with about a length of 6-7 hours.   The story itself is fine, there were some good moments in it but no way is anyone actually playing this just for that. The art / visuals on the other hand are great and is definitely what carries the series. Voice acting is good as well, they do a great job with their characters. As a special mention, I really liked the UI / menu design, it fits the theme and is easy to navigate.  If you like cute things, great. If you like catgirls, even better. If you feel ashamed at yourself by buying this remember, there are over 22,000 reviews on this game here on Steam as of writing this. It doesn’t matter if they’re all joke reviews, that’s still a lot.  If you end up enjoying Nekopara, more power to you. I know I did and I’ll definitely be playing the other volumes in the future.

comentarios: My overall rating for NEKOPARA Vol. 1: 80/100  This is a game, that does not have to be taken seriously. Or has to? This visual novel is a lovely, relaxing game, where you can find both amusement, but also deep ideas about love, friendship, loyalty and things, that accompany us in our lives. Let's see this in detail  GAMEPLAY  + Decent animations + Format + Chapter selection o Some anime clichés   I absolutely love playing this game. It is true, that I picked it as some not-so-serious game, but I was pleasantly surprised. The story is simple - the hero, Kaishou Minaduki, is opening a bakery and his two most loyal catgirls are coming to join him.  The Visual Novel format suits this game well, you are progressing through chapters and revealing the destiny of not only Kaishou and his two Catgirls - Chocola and Vanilla, but also support from his sister Shigure and the rest of Minaduki's family Catgirls - Azuki, Cinnamon, Coconut and Maple. Present times are switching with memories in the right time, so the player will not get bored.  Also setting of Catgirls role in society was interesting, many procedures are similar to our in our lives (getting of personal identification card is a metaphore to Bell exam etc.).  Only what bothered me, were some anime clichés, like to much boob shaking (I know this will bring negative points for this review :-D ), but besied that, I liked, how this novel was able to change from completely funny, to very serious and vice versa.  CHARACTERS  + Chocolla + Vanilla + Kaishou + Shigure + Steam cards, backgrounds, emoticons o Azuki, Cinnamon, Coconut, Maple  Also characters shown a variety of personalities. Kaishou is on a big crossroad of his life, full of both hopes and worries. Chocolla is a typical extrovertial person, on the opposite, Vanilla is an introvert. All of this characters are transforming, they are becoming more responsible, feeling how it is to be in love and get closer to someone.  Setting of characters is brilliant, both Chocolla and Vanilla are at the age of the first love, filled with innocence and romantic dreams. Many things are shown metaphorically, but they suit their needs.  Shigure is also important, as a younger sister she looks up to Kaishou, but also gives him important advices. The rest of Minaduki's Catgirls were just an addition, game could be also good without them, but they were not something disturbing.  Also extras as Steam Cards, backgrounds and emoticons are nice and lovely, one of few games with that accesories.  SOUNDTRACK  + Lovely according to the atmosphere + Music player + Interjections  I liked the soundtrack, it was suited for not only funny and smiling moments, but also for serious times and thoughts. Very satisfying, also as the presence of music, movie player and gallery of most conmemorable moments.  Onomatopoeia is a very important part of Japanese games and here it was used perfectly. I did not know, that so many sounds and activities can be pictured in this way!  VISUALS  + Perfect, lovely  There is nothing to complain here about, everything was right as it should be. Animy style is a bit close to Shoujo manga, but it is not overfilled with sweetness. Just several clichés, mentioned above.  SUMMARY  NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a game that should get its chance to be played. I have to say, that you need a specific mood for playing, and when you have it, the story will catch you to the very end (I finished it in two days :-D ).   I think this game should deserve a higher score, but it is suitable mostly for genre fans and most player out of it, can see this game as childish and disturbing. That is why I have chosen this evaluation.  Anyway, it is perfect and worth to try. Catgirls paradise!  PS: There is a mature version, but I have not tried it. If you would, I will not stop you, but I do not think it is necessary to spoil the nice metaphores of the game. I leave it up to you.

comentarios: To start with, The visual novel (because it's hard to call this a game) is for people to whom the anime world is nothing new. It doesn't mean that you might not like it if you are alien with those, but it is rather recommended to know the anime/manga terms.  Personally I have played several visual novels (mostly where you have choice in it) and there was one major point that shines in this game, that is animation; yes this visual novel has mostly animated scenes and characters; also to add it consists japanese dubbing with chinese, english or japanese subtitles to choose, which I especially like. The story is very interesting and reminds me a first visual novel I had played, Wanko to Kurasou. The only things I do dislike is lack of choices as there is only one story in it. It is also short (4 hours for me), but it is just volume 1.  To sum up:  [h1][b]Pluses:[/b][/h1] [list] [*]Good art [*]Consists animations [*]Interesting story [*]Well made characters [*]Upcoming sequel [/list]  [h1][b]Minuses:[/b][/h1] [list] [*]Short [*]Version with +18 scenes not avaliable on steam (without modding) [*]Lack of choices [/list]  Sounds and voice acting: 9/10 Music: 7/10 Art: 10/10 Story: 10/10 Translation: 10/10 (For English version)  [b]Overall: 9/10[/b]

comentarios: This game saved my life.  I am 27.  My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.  When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.  After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.  Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.  After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.  Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.  I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.  Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.  Thank you

comentarios: Nekopara Vol. 1 is a visual novel developed by NEKO WORKs, serving as the true beginning of the Nekopara series. It blends an endearing slice-of-life story with high-quality artwork, fully voiced characters, and an immersive presentation. This installment introduces players to the heartwarming yet comedic life of running a patisserie with adorable catgirls.    Nekopara Vol. 1 Review (Steam):  ⭐Story:   The game follows Kashou Minaduki, a young pastry chef who moves out to start his own patisserie, La Soleil. However, two of his family's catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla, sneak along and insist on staying with him. As he manages his bakery, players experience heartwarming, funny, and sometimes emotional moments with the catgirls. While the story is lighthearted and predictable, it excels in delivering wholesome and entertaining interactions.    ⭐Visuals and Art Style:   The artwork is absolutely gorgeous, featuring beautifully detailed backgrounds and expressive character sprites powered by the E-mote system, giving them lively animations. The character designs are polished and vibrant, making every scene visually delightful.    ⭐Audio and Voice Acting:   The game includes full Japanese voice acting for all the catgirls, making their personalities shine. The background music is relaxing and fits the cozy atmosphere of the patisserie setting, enhancing the overall experience.    ⭐Gameplay: As a kinetic visual novel, Nekopara Vol. 1 has no choices or branching paths—it’s a straightforward narrative experience. However, it does feature an interactive "petting system," allowing players to interact with the catgirls, adding a bit of engagement beyond just reading.    ⭐Replayability and Value: Since there are no alternate endings or choices, replay value is limited. However, fans of the series may revisit the game for its charming story, cute characters, and relaxing vibe. For newcomers, this is the best entry point into the Nekopara universe.    Final Score:   - Story: 7/10   - Visuals: 9.5/10   - Audio: 8.5/10   - Gameplay: 7/10   - Replayability: 6.5/10    Overall: 7.7/10    Conclusion:   Nekopara Vol. 1 is an excellent introduction to the series, offering a sweet and lighthearted story with stunning visuals and charming characters. While it lacks player choices, its immersive presentation and wholesome moments make it a must-play for visual novel and catgirl fans. If you enjoy cute slice-of-life narratives, this is a great pick!

comentarios: [h1]Introduction[/h1]  I'll be honest, initially I thought that my main source of enjoyment from the first entry of the Nekopara visual novels would be the sexual encounters (yes I installed the 18+ patch). As I read through, I slowly began to appreciate the personalities of the characters and the world around them. If you are looking for something to fap to, look no further, as Nekopara delivers on that front quite well. However, there is more to this visual novel adaption than eroticism.  Nekopara is developed by Neko Works, a company consisting of the original artist of the manga works, Sayori, and various programmers and scenario writers. It was localized by the famous Sekai Project, who also brought The Fruit of Grisaia and is bringing Clannad to North America. Nekopara is built on the Kirikiri engine, featuring a plugin called the "E-mote" system, which brings the characters to life through smooth animations. The opening song (OP) is Taiyou Paradise, sung by nao. The ending song (ED) is Nekomanma Biyori, sung by Haruka Shimotsuki. Nekopara was released on Steam on December 29, 2014 for $10.   [h1]Premise and Story[/h1]  Nekopara is set in a world in which some humans have been genetically modified to have cat-like features (or is it the other way around?), such as cat ears, tails, and general cat behaviour. These humanoid cats are deemed "catgirls" and are a common component of Japanese families. They are treated like normal pets and important members of the family. They can understand and communicate with humans at a basic level, although the complexities of human emotions and societal structure remain incomprehensible. In order for a catgirl to be trusted on their own in the world, they must take a Bell exam so that they can earn a Bell. These Bells signify that the catgirl wearing them is fit to walk among humans, and that their owner(s) have educated them sufficently.  The story starts with the protagonist, Minaduki Kashou, moving out of his parents' house to start up his own bakery, Patisserie La Soleil. The grammatical error is explained, I assure you. As he is unpacking his things, two medium sized boxes catch his attention. Two catgirls, the energetic, enthusiastic Chocola and the soft-spoken, subtle Vanilla spring out of the boxes, greeting their master. Kashou's younger sister, Shigure, smuggled them aboard the moving truck so that they could assist Kashou in his business. Over the course of Volume 1, the catgirls develop romantic feelings for Kashou under the guise of physical maturation, then they finally admit their feelings. Despite the fluffy and light nature of the story, there are some emotionally charged moments that enraptured me. [spoiler] Chocola shares some intimate memories of her and Vanilla's childhood early in the novel, and the last chapter involves Kashou nearly dying from overwork and the catgirls rushing to find a doctor. [/spoiler]  [h1]Gameplay and Presentation[/h1]  Nekopara is a kinetic novel, which means there are no player choices. The story is told almost entirely from Kashou's perspective. The player's interactions consist of:  Left Click/Enter: Advance text Ctrl: Skip text P: Makes characters' breasts jiggle Alt-F4: Emergency panic button  The VN is divided into 8 chapters, and each chapter is 45 minutes to an hour long, depending on how fast you read and if you listen to the voice acting (which is superb). If you decide to install the 18+ patch, there are 3 sex scenes spread out between chapters 5 - 7. Without the sex scenes, a readthrough takes about 4-5 hours, and 6-7 hours with the patch. The E-mote system provides silky smooth character animations and movements. To be honest, it's the first time I've seen this much liveliness in a visual novel, so it was impressive to me.   The art style is clean and well presented, with vibrant colours and detailed facial features. The backgrounds are relatively simple, but beautifully rendered. Almost all of the artwork was done by Sayori, the original artist of the Neko Paradise works. Not much to say about the art except that it is alluring and utterly gorgeous to look at.  All of the characters with the exception of the protagonist are fully voiced. In addition to the onscreen characters, there are unseen tertiary characters such as shop owners and passersby that are voiced as well. All audio is in Japanese, although you may set the text and interface to English, Japanese, or Chinese.   Sekai Project's localization is both accurate and humourous. Take a look at my screenshots for proof of this. Listening to the voices and comparing it to the text, I found little to no errors in the translation, and honorifics were kept untouched, which is a personal plus. Keep in mind that I am not experienced in the Japanese language, but I do know basic structure and particles. Take my words with a grain of salt.   [h1]Final Remarks/Conclusion[/h1]  In short, whether you are a fan of anthropomorphized cats or not, Nekopara is a highly enjoyable visual novel. Although the main appeal of this series is the H-scenes, the patch is optional. The Steam version was censored because of Steam's policies and to appeal to a wider audience. A quick Google search will grant you access to the adult files, so don't worry about missing out. Nekopara still offers a complete and cute experience, if a little too focused on romantic pursuits. For $10, I would say it's more than worth the asking price. It's simply [b]nyanderful![/b]

comentarios: I know these kind of games usually gather the funny styled reviews but I will try and give it a more serious one for people who are geniounly interested in Visual Novel titles (Hentai or not).   Let's start with the positives first. Everything in the game is well drawn and all characters during dialogues are animated giving it far more flair than most games of this genre which are usually consist of static images. The voice overs are decent (even though there is no choice for other languages other than Japanese), and the translators did a good job not butchering the script. Also if you apply the 18+ patch the sex scenes are well drawn and animated, so if you bought this game just for the porn aspect you will get your money's worth.    And those are all the positives of the game. Unfortunately the negatives outweight them by quite the margin. For start there are no choices to be made in the entirety of Nekopara. You just read the dialogues with no way to alter the story. And since I mentioned the story, basically there is none. It tries to tell a story of a world were humanoid cat girls exist and what is their place in the society but quickly it stops bothering. After the half hour mark it only cares about the sex and every conflict it tries to create is resolved in a couple of panels. Also, not only the game last around 2 hours it doesn't have multiple endings.   All in all, a well drawn Visual Novel with decent echhi scenes but nothing else. No decent story, no memorable characters, no multiple endings, extremely short. Get it only if you are into anime cat girls.

comentarios: The world of NEKOPARA sounds interesting enough. At some point, genetic engineering has progressed to the point where catgirls are available as pets, companions, and whatnot. Nowadays, there are less stray catgirls, and there are hints of problems with some involved in criminal activity. To combat this problem, catgirls with owners can have their pets take an exam to get a Bell collar that allows them to be monitored and walk in public by themselves.   Unfortunately for those who like visual novels with serious storylines, this is not one. Kashou leaves his strict household to open a Western-style bakery. However, two of his family's cats, Chocola and Vanilla, follow him, and refuse to leave. He ends up hiring them, and light, fluffy, slice of life romance ensues. Made somewhat awkward by his initial impression of the two as daughters, the romance is pretty much tacked on.  Thankfully, the ero scenes have been removed from the Steam release.  However, as someone who loves cats, there are some interesting questions that just don't get any answers. Catgirls, despite their humanoid appearance, age at the same rate as real cats. People refer to treating their catgirls as their children. There's a bit of fridge horror in that question. Catgirls seem to be genetically engineered to be sterile, presumably to save them the trauma of a surgery. The criminal element is not explained, though for some reason, catgirls stealing people's food, knocking things over, and causing trouble by climbing tall things comes to mind.   So do I recommend this game? That depends on the player, really. Too bad there's not a 'so-so' button. Despite that, I want to see how Kashou and his cat family do running the bakery. I'm actually curious about the background of this world. Will I like what I find? I'll find something, I'm sure.

comentarios: Alright,  Besides all the obvious content other reviewers refer to, Nekopara has many other great things going for it, besides the cute catgirls.  The backgrounds are awesome and just as beautiful as the characters. And about the characters, I've not read many VN's with that good drawing style. It's just awesome. Very detailed and very warm. Sound and music are spot on also. They fit right in and provide a very good atmosphere.  One thing though, that I don't like, is the fact that when you want to overwrite a save file or want to quit the VN; the mouse cursor moves to the "NO" button at first. I get the idea that it's funny the first tme.., but after 3, 4, 5 times...sorry. Well, that's just about the only thing that's not very good with this VN. I mean, everything else is perfect: Writing, art, cute characters and fun. Oh, about the hentai thing; this is on the green side, nothing you can't see on youtube.

I just wanted to give my kittens some milk and cream, but instead I sit here left yearning for the fap that might have been, the spank I’ll never yank, the banana I’ll never buff, the guerrilla I’ll never shave. comentarios: I once again have nothing but positive words to say about this game. following Vol.0 it has continued to be a beacon for my healing mental state, every day for months I would feel extreme emotion about going home and being able to take care of my kittens. it was a constant cycle of anxiety whenever I left my house. I didn't want my kittens to think I didn't care for them but they seemed to understand that I needed to work and would wait patiently for me to get back home. After some time though I couldn't take the anxiety and stress that was leaving my silly little bakas at home. I couldn't go a millisecond of my day without thinking about them. It got to the point where I was hearing their voices behind the counter of GameStop asking me to pet them. I couldn't hear my own thoughts and my ability to communicate with other people began to diminish. it got to the point where I couldn't even talk to people anymore. the second I stepped out of my home I heard Chocola and Vanilla begging me to come back to them. I couldn't take it. I knew that they were ok with me leaving for work but I wasn't. So good news!!! I quit!!! my anxiety and stress calmed after I was able to come back to my kittens and stay with them for my entire day. I decided to learn how to code in python, java, and c++ so I could supply for myself and my kittens from home. it was really stressful cramming 3 whole coding languages into my brain before the money my parents left me ran dry but I barely managed to make it finally landing a coding job after running out of money and eating nothing but dry cup noodles since my water was cut. Life has never been better for me though. constant feelings of joy while my catgirls are happy. My new job supplies more money than my old one and I just couldn't ask for a better situation. this game has completely revolutionized my life, making me a new person. my love for this game will never hit a limit as it is infinite. My love is ever-expanding like the universe. I genuinely cannot recommend this game more. It picked me up and put, me on my feet. it supported me through not only one mentally ill phase but two. And hey even though the second one was triggered by the game it is self it was never to hurt me. I've never been healthier and happier. this game has brought me to new highs and even though it brought me close to a low it was only for my own good as afterwords I'm better than ever. please throw your money at this game, you won't regret it.

comentarios: Ever wanted to run your own bakery, but wished that it involved less cakes and more humping of catgirls? An incestuously inclined little sister strike your fancy? Then look no more!    The sex scenes aside, the story is a cute and light-hearted one that should make you smile and then afterwards crank one out. They felt a little awkward though, as the context of the catgirls is that you supposedly raised them from kittens.   Do I recommend this? Certainly I do. If ya want the naughty stuff, you'll need to check on the forums for the patch, but the story still makes sense if you don't go down that road.   With the Nudity Patch = Great game with a cute story and fairly smooth h-scenes.  Without Nudity Patch = Great game for the whole family.

comentarios: 4/10 No backstory; is this a different world? Is it a different timeline? If it's earth did the cats mutate? Are they aliens? How did they first meet humans, etc. The overall story isn't particularly engaging.  Quite predictable as well. I didn't feel like I could relate or empathize with the main character at all. In terms of being a vn: visual novels are meant to give the player a sense of control in how they affect the storyline. The fact that the player cannot influence any of the  protagonists decisions in the VN is a fairly big deal and severely affects replayability. The game is based around the premise of "cats that are humanoid" however they don't act like cats. Cats in general I have found to be standoffish and much more self absorbed then they are portrayed in this VN and this causes the feline character to seem much more doglike. The art is amazing however, and the visual effects are quite fluid (transitions, the boob jiggle, expression changes etc.) Music was quite standard with other visual novels. Not bad but not outstanding.  In summary, subpar as a game, subpar as a visual novel but it has nice art and decent music for its genre. Not worth $10 however if you're curious pick it up if it's less then $3.   P.S If you are interested in light novels after this game, and have never read Katawa Shoujo... Go give it a go, I promise you won't be disappointed.

comentarios: I am just in love with the affection i get from these girls. I dont care if they are real because the love i have for them is. asides the point here's my review:  Kashou Minaduki is a young man with a dream. Throughout his life he’s loved baking but had to do so in private, away from the disapproving eyes of his family. One day this becomes too much to bear and Kashou suddenly moves out to finally run a brand new bakery, La Soleil. Much to his surprise, however, the nearly empty bakery has two huge shipping boxes inside – and out pop two catgirls! NEKOPARA Vol. 1 begins with an incredibly goofy anime-style bang and continues in that humorous way. You might be surprised to find, however, that there’s more to this visual novel than simple goofball antics.  What’s the deal with these catgirls? In the world of NEKOPARA there’s absolutely nothing strange about it. Apparently, catgirls live among humans normally and are often taken up as pets, workers, or romantic partners. Whatever relationships humans have with their catgirls are plainly accepted, although the protagonist seems to have a problem accepting this all as commonplace. Although they look so much like humans they still have many cat traits such as pawing madly at cat toys or drooling over fish and catnip. It’s an incredibly odd thing to consider from the get go but it almost becomes “normal” by the end of Vol. 1.  The misadventures between Kashou and his two sudden catgirl staff members, Chocola and Vanilla, start off as pretty average. Here is a guy who was fully prepared to strike out on his own when suddenly two of the family pets show up! As readers see them all interact it’s hard to not see how positive and enjoyable their presence is. In any case, the story progresses and issues grow more complicated about halfway through. Even though this is the first of a possible series of visual novels, it also ends on a high note. This is much better than the cliffhangers other titles are apt to use.  Visual novels may not require stunning graphics to be enjoyable, but all the same this one has some seriously engaging art. Of course there’s the flashy anime artwork for each character but there’s even more at play. What can’t be conveyed via screenshots A so called “E-mote” system animates each character in a lively fashion. In fact, it looks about as close as you can get to actually watching an anime series in a visual novel without going full out with animated sequences. Sometimes this does look weird though because this huge focus on E-mote means the girls are wiggling about as if they have to pee. Perhaps that’s all supposed to be cute but it comes off as distracting.

comentarios: Only one story path with only one ending. There is a story but only in the most liberal definition of one. Getting through said story is a bit of a slog and that's saying something because it's not very long. The plot goes no where and honestly the central conflict in the story is resolved in the first hour the next three is just pointless nonsense and retreading similar ground as the first hour. Really not worth the money.   The graphics are above average for a visual novel mostly in the fact that it is animated and i guess the music suits the fluff atmosphere but nothing particularly groundbreaking here. When i say animated i'm not talking School Days animated, more Tokyo School Life Animated. I can't speak much on the voice acting because i don't speak a word of Japanese. If a word or sentence was delivered awkwardly i would not know the difference.  Its only has value for the sexiness but even that's lacking unless you buy a DLC which costs as much as the game itself effectively doubling the price.   Unless you are really into fetishistic cat girls (and honestly you likely are if you are even viewing this game) or really into moe fluff where every character can be best described as ether a potato or a marshmallow or rather a combination of those, there is no way I can recommend this title. But if you are into those things then in all likelihood you have already purchased this game and as such my opinion of your moe cat porn novel is irrelevant to you.  Side note: These cat girls behave more like dogs. Real cats are jerks so I would figure a cat girl wouldn't be any different. There needs to be a dog girl game, then at least the overly inyourfaceness of the girls and the only calling you Master would make some semblance of sense. There is also the social implications of this society of cat girls but lets not get into that. (that could have made for an interesting story actually)

comentarios: this is the worst game i have ever played, bar none. never before have i felt such excruciating torment as i did while playing through this experience. each second i spent in this nightmare realm of catgirls exponentially increased my desire to throw my entire computer away and fling myself directly into the sun. upon making it to the 5th, 6th, and 7th acts of this hellish disaster of a game, after observing the "content" this game has to offer, i felt a severe urge to claw my eyeballs out which was only compounded by each consequent scene. upon playing this game, i experienced emotions i could have never imagined prior; extreme discomfort, physical and mental torment, and severe depression are nothing compared to what i felt when opening this game and experiencing it for the first time. i would rather shove myself head-first into a meat grinder than go through the pure, concentrated hell that this game is. please, for the love of all that is holy, do not subject yourself to this torment as i did. do not purchase this game, even if it and the dlc are each on sale for $4, making it an objective steal in marketing terms. this is the worst $8 i have, and ever will, spend on anything in my entire life without a doubt. it's not worth it. i beg you to consider doing literally anything else with your time, as even sitting in your chair contemplating the universe for a trillion years would be miles more productive than playing this game. the mere six hours i spent playing this do not accurately represent the torture and torment i endured, as a lifetime of struggle in the deepest reaches of hell would be the only thing that could possibly rival this. don't subject yourself to the "cute" catgirls. they are a ploy. it's all an elaborate setup to get you to fall for it, only to lure you into its devastating trap and devour you from the inside. don't subject yourself to the horrific writing, consisting of 10 minute long scenes talking about age and shampoo and fucking whale sharks. play something meaningful that can change your life for the better, or at the very least, play something that is harmless. this game is the pure embodiment of the devil himself. hell is a welcome treat in comparison to this;
